title.value: Uncertain Evidence in Probistic Models and Stochastic Simulators
title.justification: Title provided at the start of the paper.
title.quote: Uncertain Evidence in Probabilistic Models and Stochastic Simulators Andreas Munk 1 Alexander Mead 1 Frank Wood 1 2 3

extractions.description: This paper investigates Bayesian inference in probabilistic models with uncertain evidence. It evaluates different methods, including 'distributional evidence,' Jeffrey's rule, and virtual evidence, to provide insights into their consistency and applicability in such scenarios. The paper includes experiments to showcase different interpretations of uncertain evidence and their impact on latent variable inference.

type.justification: The paper mainly provides new theoretical insights and guidelines on interpreting uncertain evidence in Bayesian inference, with experiments serving to illustrate the theory.
type.quote: We explore how to interpret uncertain evidence, and by extension the importance of proper interpretation as it pertains to inference about latent variables...we provide new insights, particularly regarding consistency.

name.justification: The paper discusses Bayesian inference and uncertain evidence within the context of probabilistic models.
name.quote: We consider the problem of performing Bayesian inference in probabilistic models where observations are accompanied by uncertainty, referred to as 'uncertain evidence.'

name.justification: The examination and application of Bayesian inference methods is a significant aspect of the paper.
name.quote: In classical Bayesian inference, the task is to infer the posterior density.

name.justification: The paper addresses the interpretation of uncertain evidence in the context of stochastic simulators.
name.quote: We consider the problem of performing Bayesian inference in probabilistic models where observations are accompanied by uncertainty, referred to as 'uncertain evidence.'

name.justification: Jeffrey's rule is one of the methods evaluated in the paper for handling uncertain evidence in probabilistic models.
name.quote: inference using approach (1) or (2) corresponds to Jeffrey’s rule or virtual evidence respectively.

is_contributed.justification: Jeffrey's Rule is a well-established method in the field and was not introduced by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Of particular relevance are the work of Jeffrey (1965) and Shafer (1981); and Pearl (1988), giving rise to Jeffrey’s rule (Jeffrey, 1965; Shafer, 1981) and virtual evidence (Pearl, 1988).

is_executed.justification: The text does not specify whether Jeffrey's Rule was executed on a GPU or CPU.

is_compared.justification: Jeffrey's Rule is compared against other methods like virtual evidence and distributional evidence in the paper.
is_compared.quote: We then compare inference results from each different interpretation illustrating the importance of careful consideration of uncertain evidence.

referenced_paper_title.value: Probabilistic Reasoning in Intelligent Systems: Networks of Plausible Inference
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary work where Judea Pearl introduced the concept of Virtual Evidence.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Of particular relevance are the work of Jeffrey (1965) and Shafer (1981); and Pearl (1988), giving rise to Jeffrey’s rule (Jeffrey, 1965; Shafer, 1981) and virtual evidence (Pearl, 1988).

name.justification: Distributional evidence is a recently proposed method discussed in the paper for handling uncertain evidence in probabilistic models.
name.quote: Of particular relevance are the work of Jeffrey (1965) and Shafer (1981); and Pearl (1988), giving rise to Jeffrey’s rule (Jeffrey, 1965; Shafer, 1981) and virtual evidence (Pearl, 1988). Since then other approaches, closely related to Jeffrey’s rule and virtual evidence, has been proposed (e.g., Valtorta et al., 2002; Tolpin et al., 2021; Yao, 2022).

is_contributed.justification: Distributional Evidence, as used in this paper, has been proposed by other researchers and is not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: A third approach to uncertain evidence, recently introduced by Tolpin et al. (2021), treats the uncertain evidence on y as an event. This approach, which here is referred to as distributional evidence, defines a likelihood on the event {Y ∼ Q} (reads as 'the event that the distribution of Y is Q with density q(y)') and considers the auxiliary variable ζ = {Y ∼ Q}:

is_executed.justification: The text does not specify whether Distributional Evidence was executed on a GPU or CPU.

is_compared.justification: Distributional Evidence is compared with Jeffrey's Rule and Virtual Evidence from the perspective of Bayesian inference.
is_compared.quote: We then compare inference results from each different interpretation illustrating the importance of careful consideration of uncertain evidence.

name.quote: Approximate posterior inference is carried out with PYPROB (Baydin & Le, 2018).
